reason.tex: %text \textbf{At a point } A function $f(x)$ is continuous at the point $x=a$ if \[ \lim_{x\to a^-} f(x) = \lim_{x\to a^+}f(x) = f(a) \] That is, $f(x)$ \underline\text{converges on $f(a)$} from both the left and right of $x=a$. \textbf{Open Interval -- $(b,c)$} $f(x)$ is continuous in $ \left(b,c \right)$ if it is continuous \underline\text{for every $x\in \left(b,c \right)$ } Note that $x\in \left(b,c \right)$ means \[ \qquad x > b\text{ and } x < c\] \textbf{Closed Interval -- $\left[b,c \right]$ } In a closed interval $x\geq b$ and $x\leq c$. Therefore, for $f(x)$ to be continuous in $\left[b,c \right]$, $f(x)$ must be - Continuous in $\left(b,c \right)$ - $\lim_{x\to b^+}f(x) = f(b)$ - $\lim_{x\to c^-} f(x) = f(c)$%
